233450,Prison Architect,"If you buy this game, you may just be serving a sentence of your own...as time slips by, engroused in what you are doing. It's a fantastic managment, builder where the unpredictability of the prisoners (and pretty much everything else!) always has you interested.  The Pros: - Just one more thing: Oh how mnay times I've thought 'I'll just finish this bit and then I'll quit...no, wait, I'll do this bit too before I forget....oh and...' - Organised Chaos: Prisoners are fun to watch, can be easy or difficult to manage. I've built only 3 or four prisons (early access) and have had everything from zero problems almost at all, to a riot that started literally 3 seconds after I accidently overpowered my electricity generator (leaving one gaurd dead and many prisoners bloody and unconscious!).  - Loads of space to build - lots of info and lots to do. There's always plenty to do and work on.  - It's just damn fun and a good amouont of challenge  Take or leaves:  - Graphics: I like them, you should not be out off by them. There is a 3D mode, but it dodn't do much for me and I prefer the original personally - Prisoner mode: you can be one of the prisoners and try to escape your own or anyone else's who have shared it in the Steam workshop. It was ok when I tried it but no real sense of actually living in the prison from what I tried. A hit and giggle feature but maybe I need to check it out again.   Cons: - The tutorial and general information on how to actually play and whatthings do is very much NOT clear. I played the campaign tutorial a few times after extended breaks away from the game when it was in early access and I have avoided it this time around since its official release, so it may have been improved. But overall, you will almost certainly need to look up wikis and how to's, often for very simple thing. Thankfully, there is loads of community help and a working answer is easily found.  - Randomness that could be bugs or just lack of info: Sometimes you don't know why things are not working. Sometimes there are unclear clues, other times you 'll be cratching your heads (I have a few armed gaurds and security gaurds that gather together every night in the yard for no apparent reason. They are not scheduled to patrol there, but they do it anyway).   Really though, I find when I have a go at this game, I am sucked in for many long running sessions. Enough depth to satisfy a passionate builder/manager, not too much as to overwhelm. Eg, there are things like circuits and pressure plates, but you most definitely don't NEED them to run a prison (but it would help of course).  Very much recommended.",1,0,48740

270450,Robot Roller-Derby Disco Dodgeball,"So my friend and I were debating on whether or not to buy this game. I mean, yeah it's only $8 but we were a little strapped at the time. It looked fun, though, which is why we were hesitant. My friend decided to bite the bullet--he is the one with the better job, after all. I had to go handle my dog, so I was gone for the moment he downloaded it, but I saw the result. It was like nothing I'd ever seen before in my life. He used to be a fairly heavyset guy with pimples all over his face and an awkward demeanor; not unlike myself, though more so I suppose. The man I walked into that day was different. I saw a 6'3'' bronzed warrior with perfect facial hair and a gleam in his eye that could make any lady drop at his feet. His phone immediately started going wild with notifications about the millions being depositied into his brand-new Cayman Island account. At that moment, I knew what I had to do. I powered up my crappy laptop, barely even meeting the specs, and told Steam to install this game. At once I could feel my crotch bulging as I grew three whole feet in as many seconds. The scruffy excuse I had for a beard was replaced with a layer of hair so glorious Zeus himself was jealous as I also grew six inches taller. I wasn't a large man before, but any semblance of being out of shape melted away from my frame like butter in an oven and my muscles gained glory I'd only dreamed of before. Even my dog, who'd only been a pug before, now stood proudly by my side as a German Shepard-Husky mix while a beautiful woman appeared in my arms, who is now my wife. 271820,Card City Nights,"I bought this game when I only had a Netbook available to play games on. Had it on my wishlist since release and it's extremely cheap in comparison with some other games, so I just thought 'Why not?' and bought it. After starting the game you choose a character and give yourself a name. You're new in town and how else could it be, the whole town is crazy for card battles. The main goal of the game is to collect all legendary cards by beating the owners of those cards and finally beat the Card King. On your way you get to see lots of crazy looking, humorous characters and get to hear some nice chilling-jazzy tunes.  What I really like about this game is, that it's extremely fast and easy to learn, yet fun to manage your deck and finally use it in a card battle. To explain it very roughly, most Cards have arrows on them or some special effects and you just have to connect them on a 3x3 board to create combos using Cards that sum up to at least 3 Icons. Cards have one of four Icons on them, Attack, Defense, Revive and Neutral. Using attack Cards you can either attack your opponent and he'll loose 'defense' (just like Health Points) or disable one of your opponent cards, so he can't use 'em until he revives them using Revive Cards. Using Defense Cards will fill up your defense until you reach the maximum of 10 defense. Neutral Cards can come in handy when connecting Cards. You win a game when your opponent can't place a card on his 3x3 Board or he runs out of defense. Most opponents give you a card booster as a reward and you can also buy or fuse cards. I haven't spent much time collecting Cards, I just went on with the Cards I owned and updated my deck now and then, mostly only changing the legendary Card or replacing one or two Cards from my deck with Cards I got from a Booster.  While - at least in my opinion - you should never judge a game on how long it is (you don't pay 10 $ for a visit to the cinema and regret it because the movie was only 2 hours long, right?), Card City Nights entertained me for about 11 hours until I've beaten the whole game and got all the Achievements, which is quite long for a game that price. Instead a game should be judged by how fun it was to play and I really had fun playing it. I definitely recommend this game. It's fun, it's cheap, it has Steam Trading Cards and Steam Achievements. So: Why not?",1,0,11770
233450,Prison Architect, Early Access Review,1,0,11857

251730,Legend of Grimrock 2,"Let me start off by saying I may complain a bit in this review but I still recommend this game. Also these are just my opinions of the game, I am sure there are many people who will say 'well I did not experience these problems blah blah blah' what I am saying is don't be butthurt by my opinion this is just what I have experience and felt for myself.   Cons-   Some puzzles are highly frustrating or very cryptic while I enjoy difficult puzzles some are extremely hard to decifer which can lead to frustration in people new to this type of game.  Some classes seem good but in reality they are not take the knight his dodge increase with shields is broken or at least it looks broken to me (will be patched if it is im sure)  Was not impressed with the alchemist guns there never seemed to be enough ammo and the guns were scarce. Potion making was awesome though.  Exploration was very fun in the beginning but later on it got very frustrating (for me).  Spells seemed weak IMO at times they would hit hard but most of the time even if the monster was weak to it they seemed over all weaker from the last game.  Characters seem to miss allot even if you get accuracy up until you get into the upper levels of accuracy.  Monsters can hit you over and over and over at times while you wait to recharge your characters attacks.  Near the end the boss fights just throw enemies at you which is not very fun they could have done something different with the boss fights to make them more interesting.  Puzzles get a little tedious after awhile because they are mostly just redos from previous puzzles with little differences.  Underwater battles are irritating especially if you don't have a trident or spear.  Not a whole lot of enemy variation.  I felt there were not a whole lot of weapon variations either but this may be nitpicking.  No voice acting from the master of the island (I feel a mysterious voice talking on his notes and maybe a random sentence when sleeping or something would have been awesome).  I know that most of the story is figured out with stone heads and notes from the island master but I feel at times besides looking for a way off the island you really didn't know why you were exploring the areas looking for power gems.  Armor sets do not have set bonuses so finding them all is good but doesn't make much of a difference.   Pros  I like the night and day cycle especially for some of the puzzles.  weapon special attacks were pretty good.  graphics looked good.(not that this really should count for scoring a game.)  Level design was great in most areas and it kept it fresh to have different level designs.  Most puzzles were fun to solve.  Map in this game is extremely helpful so is the compass and watch.  The armor sets looks cool even if they didn't get set bonuses.  Each enemy had unique attacks (don't drop the ethereal dagger)  Sound effects were done very well.  Potions made are very useful.  For the price lots of hours of gameplay especially with workshop dungeons and such.  Good unique character races with good pros and cons to using them.  While I enjoyed this game I also got much more frustrated with this one, way more than I did with the first one which is very very awesome (mine is owned from Good old Games and not in my steam account). By the time I got to the end of this game I was ready for it to be over, maybe I should have taken a break from it but it was interesting enough that I wanted to finish it. I will be taking a long break from it and then downloading allot of workshop dungeons when they become available and I feel like playing some more.  Graphics 7/10 Sound 8/10 Combat 5/10 Gameplay 7/10 Story 4/10 Replayability 9/10  Final score 6.6 or 7 rounded up definately worth getting.",1,0,11975

233450,Prison Architect,"Great game, played throught the BETA trials and was constantly improving! if you like sim games this is a must!!",1,0,12407
233450,Prison Architect,"First off I just want to say I was surprised by how well the campaign was written. I wasn't expecting much but it has quite some emotional impact.  The game itself is fun! There seems to be many possible ways to construct and run your prison, and I'd say the replayability is fairly high. It seems mostly bug-free and is functioning very well. It's mostly a very satisfying experience, if you like these kind of 'build and manage'-games.  It has some problems though. The most appearant is money balance. I'm not sure if I'm just playing it wrong, but I found it hard to earn money in a pace that allowed me to keep constructing and improving my prison without spending a lot of time waiting for money to tick in. There are some small glitches, the most annoying one i encountered was that my doctors kept getting stuck in the walls of my infirmary for some reason. I could fix it by ordering them to move somewhere, but until I did that, they would not function as usual. And after a while they'd end up stuck again. Firing them an rehiring didn't fix it. Some of the requirements for rooms are somewhat unclear. A couple of times I ended up rebuilding buildings because the room wouldn't function, only to later figure out I had made some stupid mistake like not tagging all squares in the building as part of the room. There is a bit of information that is hard or impossible to access in-game, and you have to go look at a wiki or something to figure it out. For example, connecting CCTVs to a monitor only works if you connect from the monitor to the cctv. if you connect from the cctv to the monitor, it doesn't work. There is no tutorial for these things in the campaign and that limitation is so incredibly odd yet mentioned nowhere in the game.  It looks like I've listed a lot of negatives, but most of them are actually relatively minor complaints. I've had a lot of fun with this game and it was well worth the money spent.",1,0,12679

233450,Prison Architect,"Figured I should get around to a review of this game after 100+ hrs..  Overview: Prison Architect is a game that allows you to construct, manage, and be sentenced to a prison of your own making with a large variety of features.  I typically do a pros/cons section in my reviews, but it's difficult to do that with Prison Architect. The game gives you the freedom to do pretty much everything with the tools it (or modders!) provide you. The AI for the prisoners and staff isn't bad, negatives like contraband, prisoner tension, and needs are fairly balanced with your mitigation options (Which require some thought in implementation!).  This game is everything you'd expect for what it is. The only true downsides that come to mind is that prisoners don't always satisfy their biggest need first (Such as not using the toliet sitting in their cells before going to the shower, then starting a fight over it.)  Vinal Verdict: Solid 9/10. Great game that's constantly being improved!",1,0,15739

251730,Legend of Grimrock 2,"Legend of Grimrock 2 (here on referred to as LoG 2) is everything you could want for a sequel and more. I look forward to what the future holds with user generated content.  The Legend of Grimrock series are a set of real time, grid based, dungeon crawlers with pleasing graphics and a good aesthetic.   Movement is based on grid and you can turn left and right also move left, right, forward and backwards. You attack by clicking the weapon of choice from the character portraits. While this is not for everyone, it's stays true to it's roots and will please many after they have adapted.  While the story is a little weak, you will find yourself enjoying the neatly packaged puzzles that are littered throughout the world. I had a problem with the first game where you had to search each wall for secret buttons or risk missing one. LoG 2 improves on this by giving some subtle and some not so subtle hints that the player is missing something and should look deeper, resulting in a less difficult search.  Another area that LoG 2 improves upon is allowing the user access to outside areas, giving more varied feel to the game. There are now many more types of enemies and many of which have varied A.I.  The soundtrack has seen improvements since the first game and has a lovely score of atmospheric ambient noise and battle music for boss fights. The theme tune is catchy but I still see myself returning to the theme song of the first game.  In conclusion my experience with Legend of Grimrock 2 was amazing and to top off it all, there is extensive support of modifications, I look forward to seeing what people create.  Controller Support : Not suitable for a controller. Fully playable with just a mouse.",1,0,17458

Boy, while it was buggy and laggy, I enjoyed every moment the alpha 10 provided and the next alphas as well. Some alphas had major bug fixing, some adding contents and a lot more. I edited a lot pages in the wikia of Prison Architect (The legal ones, aka, dev ones) and so on.  Now it got released. Is it really worth to buy this game? Absolutely YES! Are you the type of city building, money management, staff management, resource management, time management? Then this is your game.  At first you can do tutorial by doing missions. But the truth is, the tutorials do not really help you understand how the game works so you are forced to either watch some youtube videos or just check the wikias.  No problem! The  major positive  here is, the sandbox.   Unlike most other games which their sandbox often end because we filled out everything we had. For example, a survival horror with resources, if we got all resources, weapons to win our enemies, then we have nothing else to do because we got unlimited days to survive, etcetera.  So yeah, the sandbox is kinda limited, ESPECIALLY if you play it without money cheats or with challenges (Gangs, events temperature) and what not. If you got gangs ticked (Means they will make an appearance) it will add a challenge to the game and so on. On the other hand, you got a few guard types, one is a normal guard, one guard dog, one armed guard and so on and each of them got different roles and responsibilities! You can also hire cooks, janitors, gardeners and so on.  What you have to be really careful is, prisoners. They humans and express their needs by anger, arguing, fighting or worse, rioting. Riots is the worse challenge because if the prison is taken and hasnt been stopped for long time, the government will send military to take it over, thus marking it as game over (Unless FAILURE CONDITIONS are disabled).  Now, prisoners can eat, relax, sleep, work or attend to reform programs. That's good. On the bad, they will fight, be in a gang, escape from the prison, attack prison staff or other inmates.  You can build the prison YOU would like. You can make small cells, large cells, small canteen, huge yard and a lot more. NO limitations, you decide what you want! There are a lot rooms, a lot buildings to build, a lot staff to hire, a lot objects to place for a use, everything is everything, the sandbox simply never ends itself. You can even have more than 1000+ prisoners and the sandbox wont end, more challenges will come and more hard stuff.  There is escape mode too where you play as prisoner and escape from a prison, yours or someones. You can hire gangs, use tools to escape and so on but is too simple but fun.  And last pros, there is 3D mode which is very laggy and underdeveloped at the moment. You can download ANY mod you want from workshop!   On cons , the game has some very minor bugs which can be hardly noticeable unless you try hard. The lag is depending of your computer's processor, it has nothing to do with graphics card at most times.  This game is the best prison game I have ever played, better than Prison Tycoon. No other words, just no other words! I vote it...   8.5/10. Personally, I am recommending this game to ANYONE and especially to those who live kind management games which has endless sandbox mode and more good features. I dislike however, some bugs gone unnoticed and some lack features which in-real life prisons have such as multi-floor story, hostage situations and some. ",1,0,33625

233450,Prison Architect, Early Access Review,1,0,44437
233450,Prison Architect,"Update after 160 hours!   Prison Architect is 'sandbox' builder par excellance. I have had the pleasure of seeing it grow and improve over the last half a year and it draws me back in every time. There are no cons, just so you know :P  But what's Prison Architect?  You are the Boss. Your prison, your rules, your design.  Start from scratch and work your way up the ladder until you can house the most dangerous criminals. Or go into the unlimited fund mode and just build your personal dream prison.   Prison Architect offers a variety of complex mechanics that work neatly with each other to create a living, changing prison environment.   Building: classical square-based, bird eye sandbox.   Environment: day and night cycle, proper shadows, chances of lakes and woods to be incorporated into your design. grass and flowers will grow uncontrollably and need to be trimmed.   Gangs: criminals will now sometimes have gang affiliations. they will fight you and other prisoners and even take over your prison!! They come in all shapes and sizes, and some are even docile.  Needs: prisoners have several needs they shout at you, from the easy 'Bladder' to the more difficult to reach 'Safety'. Family visits will do a lot to release stress. it's a constant fight to keep them happy, but understanding their needs is key for running a tidy prison.  Contraband: Ah, you can try, but you will have a hard time preventing smuggling inside your prison. Your prisoners steal, have help from their families or have packages thrown over the fences. Fight back with metal detectors, routine searches and confidental informants.  Wiretap the phones for additional insight and shake down your prison every once in a while (or daily :D )  Guards: Regular, Armed and Dog Handlers, plus an extra Riot Unit to call in emergencies. station them on posts, let them patrol or teach each of them how to use tazers. they're not the smartest, but loyal to the death. Dog Handlers will sniff out smelly contraband or tunnels, while armed guards are great at keeping your inmates surpressed. be sure to plan their routes properly and concentrate forces at critical points.  Rooms: a large variety of rooms, from different cell types (holding cells, solitary, regular) to security stations and armories to libraries and laundries for the prisoners. build a dog pound, common room or even a chapel for the those that want to find salvation in the arms of the lord. Cells have a quality, directly incluencing the inmates' behaviour. always good to have an eye on that ;)  Staff: Psychologists for intimate group seminars with the prisoners, grounds keepers, cooks and, of course, a lawyer and accountant. Let them research, clean and fend off annoying lawsuits or loss conditions. I told you, you are the boss :P  Prisoners: now, they are the true heroes of this game. quite clever and crafty little s. They will stop at nothing to try to escape you or send the prison spiraling down into a muderious abyss of blood and mayhem. building tunnels together with other prisoners. stealing the appropriate tools from around the prison. shanking suspicious inmates in the shower. initiating riots when a prisoner dies. Prisoners come in all forms and shapes. from the mid 20 stoner, in for possession, to deathrow inmates with multiple murders. some have abilites, some are even legen-wait for it-dary. and you decide their security level ;)  Snitchs and Ex Law Enforcement inmates are a painful joy. not fast enough in identifying them? see them shanked to death in the shower, yard or laundry.  There's a huge variety of prisoners, crimes and reputation skills, and each prisoner is indeed somewhat of an individual.  Intelligence: recruit confidental informants, check the history of contraband and control your gangs. but be careful, the more you rely on your informants, the more likely they are to be killed by their fellow inmates.  Logistics: still a bit of a pain in the  to get around with, but you can control who is washing which wings' clothes, preps their food etc.   Size: as they say, it doesn't matter. try to manage a small prison with few but maybe violent inmates, or go ballistic with hundreds of prisoners, likely suffocating in their own filth. Prison architect is fun from small to big. But always a challenge.  Random Events: Fires, floods, virus outbreaks and surprise prisoners, all the things you need to ruin your day.  While a burst pipe is easily taken care of, a fire can surely burn down large parts of your prison and kill many an inmate or staffer. Be sure to have either a quarantine ward ready for outbreaks, or to isolate the affected prisoners in their cells quickly.  Prison Policy Events: You can't run a prison without some politician or the other trying to boss you around. They will ask you to serve your prisoners the lowest grade food or to remove all work out benches from the yards, because some one clearly does not want your prison to be peaceful. ignore it and get annoyed by phone calls every few ingame hours, or just do as they ask and deal with the fallout. probably by bashing in heads and locking up half your prison  Campaign: a lovely little story revolving around betrayal, murder and mayhem, also serving as a perfect tutorial for the sandbox mode. The campaign introduces the mechanics in an understandable and easy to grasp way for new comers, and even after 100 hours, it still offered insight for my gameplay.  There is so much more going on, but seriously, 110 hours into the game I feel like I barely scratched the surface of what Prison Architect really has to offer. Even now, after 160 hours, it still sucks me in for 5 -10 hours a time. From the urge to build more and better wards to just observing the prisoners and try to keep the place calm, there is much to do and even more to observe.   Get it. This game is worth every Euro and Stotinki and will make you forget about everything else. There's still some bugs left, but the devs are still putting out updates, and so far the game as steadily improved.  I know I have probably been neglecting huge parts of the game in this review, but heck, I'm just one man trying to keep people locked up.",1,0,44522
233450,Prison Architect, Early Access Review,1,0,44639
202200,Galactic Civilizations II: Ultimate Edition,"Sure, create account. Well doesent work...contact support.  off......  Edit. After trying again and again i found username what was free and got to play this game. Good game so far....",1,0,44644

35700,Trine,"I highly recommend this game if you're a fan of puzzle solving games, like smashing the hell out of skeletons and if you like the idea of having 3 characters merged into 1.  Firstly, I got this in a package in the Christmas sale and didn't think I was going to play it. I installed it due to it's small file size and thought 'Meh, let's see what this is like.' I didn't get off it... It's a fantastic game with 3 characters that you can find different perk items for to maximise their abilities. It's also a great puzzle solving game as you have to use your initiative to navigate the missions. The wizard has awesome powers to conjur up platforms, boxes and bridges. The thief is great because she can reach high up places and the knight is just kickass for when you have a lot of enemies around you. I favoured the thief the most due to her ability to grapple onto any wooden surface and climb the grapple rope. Following her closely I favoured the wizard as he can get your other characters around very fast. I love the idea of having 3 characters merged into one interchangable character, makes the gameplay really smooth.This game took me 5 and a half hours to complete, and that was on medium. The last mission is pretty insane and very fast paced. It has a great immersive world and it can keep you occupied for ages. Great time killer as the missions aren't massively long but there are nifty little hide-aways that have experience vials and chests, that if you play with the intention to fully play a mission, can take you quite a while.   For a 2.5D game it is very enjoyable, I highly recommend it.   8/10",1,0,44962

251730,Legend of Grimrock 2,"This is essentially Legend of Grimrock, but more. There's a greater variety of enemies, the skill point system is tighter, there are different environments to traverse instead of an eternity of brick-and-moss walls to bump listlessly into, the fan community is generally helpful, and the game *can* be beaten by a casual dungeon-crawler without the need to refer to a walkthrough every five steps. That said, there are several major optional dungeons, old areas repopulate with new encounters after milestones in the plot, puzzle hints are scattered between zones to make back-tracks more productive, and classes have been added to the game, supplementing the new races with a broader range of build options at the game's start.  Grim II is substantially more intuitive, with the worst puzzles being largely optional and timing-gimmick traps an occasional thing, rather than a whenever-the-developers-got-bored kind of affair. Pixel-hunt walls are also less in evidence (although the workshop community is working dilligently to fix that,) and fish restock themselves in ponds and rivers to cut down on starvation-induced unwinnable game-states.   It is still possible to get locked into an unrecoverable state (invincible golems start appearing midway through the plot, and they can wall-abuse you into a corner if you're unlucky,) but rotating your saves will prevent this handidly.  Basically: if you even sort of liked the original game, you're going to have a good time.  If you didn't much care for Grim 1's formula, but you liked Eye of the Beholder or Ultima Underworld or similar titles, this is still worth a try.   The only people I'd suggest give this a miss are people who want a smooth, continuous flow of play ala Halo, CoD, Skyrim, etc. Grimrock is largely about stopping and thinking about how you're going to proceed, and folks who have a strong negative reaction to things like substitution ciphers would do well to stay clear.",1,0,46786

233450,Prison Architect,"If you buy this game, you may just be serving a sentence of your own...as time slips by, engroused in what you are doing. It's a fantastic managment, builder where the unpredictability of the prisoners (and pretty much everything else!) always has you interested.  The Pros: - Just one more thing: Oh how mnay times I've thought 'I'll just finish this bit and then I'll quit...no, wait, I'll do this bit too before I forget....oh and...' - Organised Chaos: Prisoners are fun to watch, can be easy or difficult to manage. I've built only 3 or four prisons (early access) and have had everything from zero problems almost at all, to a riot that started literally 3 seconds after I accidently overpowered my electricity generator (leaving one gaurd dead and many prisoners bloody and unconscious!).  - Loads of space to build - lots of info and lots to do. There's always plenty to do and work on.  - It's just damn fun and a good amouont of challenge  Take or leaves:  - Graphics: I like them, you should not be out off by them. There is a 3D mode, but it dodn't do much for me and I prefer the original personally - Prisoner mode: you can be one of the prisoners and try to escape your own or anyone else's who have shared it in the Steam workshop. It was ok when I tried it but no real sense of actually living in the prison from what I tried. A hit and giggle feature but maybe I need to check it out again.   Cons: - The tutorial and general information on how to actually play and whatthings do is very much NOT clear. I played the campaign tutorial a few times after extended breaks away from the game when it was in early access and I have avoided it this time around since its official release, so it may have been improved. But overall, you will almost certainly need to look up wikis and how to's, often for very simple thing. Thankfully, there is loads of community help and a working answer is easily found.  - Randomness that could be bugs or just lack of info: Sometimes you don't know why things are not working. Sometimes there are unclear clues, other times you 'll be cratching your heads (I have a few armed gaurds and security gaurds that gather together every night in the yard for no apparent reason. They are not scheduled to patrol there, but they do it anyway).   Really though, I find when I have a go at this game, I am sucked in for many long running sessions. Enough depth to satisfy a passionate builder/manager, not too much as to overwhelm. Eg, there are things like circuits and pressure plates, but you most definitely don't NEED them to run a prison (but it would help of course).  Very much recommended.",1,0,48740

270450,Robot Roller-Derby Disco Dodgeball,"So my friend and I were debating on whether or not to buy this game. I mean, yeah it's only $8 but we were a little strapped at the time. It looked fun, though, which is why we were hesitant. My friend decided to bite the bullet--he is the one with the better job, after all. I had to go handle my dog, so I was gone for the moment he downloaded it, but I saw the result. It was like nothing I'd ever seen before in my life. He used to be a fairly heavyset guy with pimples all over his face and an awkward demeanor; not unlike myself, though more so I suppose. The man I walked into that day was different. I saw a 6'3'' bronzed warrior with perfect facial hair and a gleam in his eye that could make any lady drop at his feet. His phone immediately started going wild with notifications about the millions being depositied into his brand-new Cayman Island account. At that moment, I knew what I had to do. I powered up my crappy laptop, barely even meeting the specs, and told Steam to install this game. At once I could feel my crotch bulging as I grew three whole feet in as many seconds. The scruffy excuse I had for a beard was replaced with a layer of hair so glorious Zeus himself was jealous as I also grew six inches taller. I wasn't a large man before, but any semblance of being out of shape melted away from my frame like butter in an oven and my muscles gained glory I'd only dreamed of before. Even my dog, who'd only been a pug before, now stood proudly by my side as a German Shepard-Husky mix while a beautiful woman appeared in my arms, who is now my wife. 271820,Card City Nights,"I bought this game when I only had a Netbook available to play games on. Had it on my wishlist since release and it's extremely cheap in comparison with some other games, so I just thought 'Why not?' and bought it. After starting the game you choose a character and give yourself a name. You're new in town and how else could it be, the whole town is crazy for card battles. The main goal of the game is to collect all legendary cards by beating the owners of those cards and finally beat the Card King. On your way you get to see lots of crazy looking, humorous characters and get to hear some nice chilling-jazzy tunes.  What I really like about this game is, that it's extremely fast and easy to learn, yet fun to manage your deck and finally use it in a card battle. To explain it very roughly, most Cards have arrows on them or some special effects and you just have to connect them on a 3x3 board to create combos using Cards that sum up to at least 3 Icons. Cards have one of four Icons on them, Attack, Defense, Revive and Neutral. Using attack Cards you can either attack your opponent and he'll loose 'defense' (just like Health Points) or disable one of your opponent cards, so he can't use 'em until he revives them using Revive Cards. Using Defense Cards will fill up your defense until you reach the maximum of 10 defense. Neutral Cards can come in handy when connecting Cards. You win a game when your opponent can't place a card on his 3x3 Board or he runs out of defense. Most opponents give you a card booster as a reward and you can also buy or fuse cards. I haven't spent much time collecting Cards, I just went on with the Cards I owned and updated my deck now and then, mostly only changing the legendary Card or replacing one or two Cards from my deck with Cards I got from a Booster.  While - at least in my opinion - you should never judge a game on how long it is (you don't pay 10 $ for a visit to the cinema and regret it because the movie was only 2 hours long, right?), Card City Nights entertained me for about 11 hours until I've beaten the whole game and got all the Achievements, which is quite long for a game that price. Instead a game should be judged by how fun it was to play and I really had fun playing it. I definitely recommend this game. It's fun, it's cheap, it has Steam Trading Cards and Steam Achievements. So: Why not?",1,0,11770
233450,Prison Architect, Early Access Review,1,0,11857

251730,Legend of Grimrock 2,"Let me start off by saying I may complain a bit in this review but I still recommend this game. Also these are just my opinions of the game, I am sure there are many people who will say 'well I did not experience these problems blah blah blah' what I am saying is don't be butthurt by my opinion this is just what I have experience and felt for myself.   Cons-   Some puzzles are highly frustrating or very cryptic while I enjoy difficult puzzles some are extremely hard to decifer which can lead to frustration in people new to this type of game.  Some classes seem good but in reality they are not take the knight his dodge increase with shields is broken or at least it looks broken to me (will be patched if it is im sure)  Was not impressed with the alchemist guns there never seemed to be enough ammo and the guns were scarce. Potion making was awesome though.  Exploration was very fun in the beginning but later on it got very frustrating (for me).  Spells seemed weak IMO at times they would hit hard but most of the time even if the monster was weak to it they seemed over all weaker from the last game.  Characters seem to miss allot even if you get accuracy up until you get into the upper levels of accuracy.  Monsters can hit you over and over and over at times while you wait to recharge your characters attacks.  Near the end the boss fights just throw enemies at you which is not very fun they could have done something different with the boss fights to make them more interesting.  Puzzles get a little tedious after awhile because they are mostly just redos from previous puzzles with little differences.  Underwater battles are irritating especially if you don't have a trident or spear.  Not a whole lot of enemy variation.  I felt there were not a whole lot of weapon variations either but this may be nitpicking.  No voice acting from the master of the island (I feel a mysterious voice talking on his notes and maybe a random sentence when sleeping or something would have been awesome).  I know that most of the story is figured out with stone heads and notes from the island master but I feel at times besides looking for a way off the island you really didn't know why you were exploring the areas looking for power gems.  Armor sets do not have set bonuses so finding them all is good but doesn't make much of a difference.   Pros  I like the night and day cycle especially for some of the puzzles.  weapon special attacks were pretty good.  graphics looked good.(not that this really should count for scoring a game.)  Level design was great in most areas and it kept it fresh to have different level designs.  Most puzzles were fun to solve.  Map in this game is extremely helpful so is the compass and watch.  The armor sets looks cool even if they didn't get set bonuses.  Each enemy had unique attacks (don't drop the ethereal dagger)  Sound effects were done very well.  Potions made are very useful.  For the price lots of hours of gameplay especially with workshop dungeons and such.  Good unique character races with good pros and cons to using them.  While I enjoyed this game I also got much more frustrated with this one, way more than I did with the first one which is very very awesome (mine is owned from Good old Games and not in my steam account). By the time I got to the end of this game I was ready for it to be over, maybe I should have taken a break from it but it was interesting enough that I wanted to finish it. I will be taking a long break from it and then downloading allot of workshop dungeons when they become available and I feel like playing some more.  Graphics 7/10 Sound 8/10 Combat 5/10 Gameplay 7/10 Story 4/10 Replayability 9/10  Final score 6.6 or 7 rounded up definately worth getting.",1,0,11975

233450,Prison Architect,"First off I just want to say I was surprised by how well the campaign was written. I wasn't expecting much but it has quite some emotional impact.  The game itself is fun! There seems to be many possible ways to construct and run your prison, and I'd say the replayability is fairly high. It seems mostly bug-free and is functioning very well. It's mostly a very satisfying experience, if you like these kind of 'build and manage'-games.  It has some problems though. The most appearant is money balance. I'm not sure if I'm just playing it wrong, but I found it hard to earn money in a pace that allowed me to keep constructing and improving my prison without spending a lot of time waiting for money to tick in. There are some small glitches, the most annoying one i encountered was that my doctors kept getting stuck in the walls of my infirmary for some reason. I could fix it by ordering them to move somewhere, but until I did that, they would not function as usual. And after a while they'd end up stuck again. Firing them an rehiring didn't fix it. Some of the requirements for rooms are somewhat unclear. A couple of times I ended up rebuilding buildings because the room wouldn't function, only to later figure out I had made some stupid mistake like not tagging all squares in the building as part of the room. There is a bit of information that is hard or impossible to access in-game, and you have to go look at a wiki or something to figure it out. For example, connecting CCTVs to a monitor only works if you connect from the monitor to the cctv. if you connect from the cctv to the monitor, it doesn't work. There is no tutorial for these things in the campaign and that limitation is so incredibly odd yet mentioned nowhere in the game.  It looks like I've listed a lot of negatives, but most of them are actually relatively minor complaints. I've had a lot of fun with this game and it was well worth the money spent.",1,0,12679

233450,Prison Architect,"Figured I should get around to a review of this game after 100+ hrs..  Overview: Prison Architect is a game that allows you to construct, manage, and be sentenced to a prison of your own making with a large variety of features.  I typically do a pros/cons section in my reviews, but it's difficult to do that with Prison Architect. The game gives you the freedom to do pretty much everything with the tools it (or modders!) provide you. The AI for the prisoners and staff isn't bad, negatives like contraband, prisoner tension, and needs are fairly balanced with your mitigation options (Which require some thought in implementation!).  This game is everything you'd expect for what it is. The only true downsides that come to mind is that prisoners don't always satisfy their biggest need first (Such as not using the toliet sitting in their cells before going to the shower, then starting a fight over it.)  Vinal Verdict: Solid 9/10. Great game that's constantly being improved!",1,0,15739

251730,Legend of Grimrock 2,"Legend of Grimrock 2 (here on referred to as LoG 2) is everything you could want for a sequel and more. I look forward to what the future holds with user generated content.  The Legend of Grimrock series are a set of real time, grid based, dungeon crawlers with pleasing graphics and a good aesthetic.   Movement is based on grid and you can turn left and right also move left, right, forward and backwards. You attack by clicking the weapon of choice from the character portraits. While this is not for everyone, it's stays true to it's roots and will please many after they have adapted.  While the story is a little weak, you will find yourself enjoying the neatly packaged puzzles that are littered throughout the world. I had a problem with the first game where you had to search each wall for secret buttons or risk missing one. LoG 2 improves on this by giving some subtle and some not so subtle hints that the player is missing something and should look deeper, resulting in a less difficult search.  Another area that LoG 2 improves upon is allowing the user access to outside areas, giving more varied feel to the game. There are now many more types of enemies and many of which have varied A.I.  The soundtrack has seen improvements since the first game and has a lovely score of atmospheric ambient noise and battle music for boss fights. The theme tune is catchy but I still see myself returning to the theme song of the first game.  In conclusion my experience with Legend of Grimrock 2 was amazing and to top off it all, there is extensive support of modifications, I look forward to seeing what people create.  Controller Support : Not suitable for a controller. Fully playable with just a mouse.",1,0,17458

233450,Prison Architect,"Okay, I first time bought this game when it was in early access alpha 10. Boy, while it was buggy and laggy, I enjoyed every moment the alpha 10 provided and the next alphas as well. Some alphas had major bug fixing, some adding contents and a lot more. I edited a lot pages in the wikia of Prison Architect (The legal ones, aka, dev ones) and so on.  Now it got released. Is it really worth to buy this game? Absolutely YES! Are you the type of city building, money management, staff management, resource management, time management? Then this is your game.  At first you can do tutorial by doing missions. But the truth is, the tutorials do not really help you understand how the game works so you are forced to either watch some youtube videos or just check the wikias.  No problem! The  major positive  here is, the sandbox.   Unlike most other games which their sandbox often end because we filled out everything we had. For example, a survival horror with resources, if we got all resources, weapons to win our enemies, then we have nothing else to do because we got unlimited days to survive, etcetera.  So yeah, the sandbox is kinda limited, ESPECIALLY if you play it without money cheats or with challenges (Gangs, events temperature) and what not. If you got gangs ticked (Means they will make an appearance) it will add a challenge to the game and so on. On the other hand, you got a few guard types, one is a normal guard, one guard dog, one armed guard and so on and each of them got different roles and responsibilities! You can also hire cooks, janitors, gardeners and so on.  What you have to be really careful is, prisoners. They humans and express their needs by anger, arguing, fighting or worse, rioting. Riots is the worse challenge because if the prison is taken and hasnt been stopped for long time, the government will send military to take it over, thus marking it as game over (Unless FAILURE CONDITIONS are disabled).  Now, prisoners can eat, relax, sleep, work or attend to reform programs. That's good. On the bad, they will fight, be in a gang, escape from the prison, attack prison staff or other inmates.  You can build the prison YOU would like. You can make small cells, large cells, small canteen, huge yard and a lot more. NO limitations, you decide what you want! There are a lot rooms, a lot buildings to build, a lot staff to hire, a lot objects to place for a use, everything is everything, the sandbox simply never ends itself. You can even have more than 1000+ prisoners and the sandbox wont end, more challenges will come and more hard stuff.  There is escape mode too where you play as prisoner and escape from a prison, yours or someones. You can hire gangs, use tools to escape and so on but is too simple but fun.  And last pros, there is 3D mode which is very laggy and underdeveloped at the moment. You can download ANY mod you want from workshop!   On cons , the game has some very minor bugs which can be hardly noticeable unless you try hard. The lag is depending of your computer's processor, it has nothing to do with graphics card at most times.  This game is the best prison game I have ever played, better than Prison Tycoon. No other words, just no other words! I vote it...   8.5/10. Personally, I am recommending this game to ANYONE and especially to those who live kind management games which has endless sandbox mode and more good features. I dislike however, some bugs gone unnoticed and some lack features which in-real life prisons have such as multi-floor story, hostage situations and some. ",1,0,33625

233450,Prison Architect, Early Access Review,1,0,44437
233450,Prison Architect,"Update after 160 hours!   Prison Architect is 'sandbox' builder par excellance. I have had the pleasure of seeing it grow and improve over the last half a year and it draws me back in every time. There are no cons, just so you know :P  But what's Prison Architect?  You are the Boss. Your prison, your rules, your design.  Start from scratch and work your way up the ladder until you can house the most dangerous criminals. Or go into the unlimited fund mode and just build your personal dream prison.   Prison Architect offers a variety of complex mechanics that work neatly with each other to create a living, changing prison environment.   Building: classical square-based, bird eye sandbox.   Environment: day and night cycle, proper shadows, chances of lakes and woods to be incorporated into your design. grass and flowers will grow uncontrollably and need to be trimmed.   Gangs: criminals will now sometimes have gang affiliations. they will fight you and other prisoners and even take over your prison!! They come in all shapes and sizes, and some are even docile.  Needs: prisoners have several needs they shout at you, from the easy 'Bladder' to the more difficult to reach 'Safety'. Family visits will do a lot to release stress. it's a constant fight to keep them happy, but understanding their needs is key for running a tidy prison.  Contraband: Ah, you can try, but you will have a hard time preventing smuggling inside your prison. Your prisoners steal, have help from their families or have packages thrown over the fences. Fight back with metal detectors, routine searches and confidental informants.  Wiretap the phones for additional insight and shake down your prison every once in a while (or daily :D )  Guards: Regular, Armed and Dog Handlers, plus an extra Riot Unit to call in emergencies. station them on posts, let them patrol or teach each of them how to use tazers. they're not the smartest, but loyal to the death. Dog Handlers will sniff out smelly contraband or tunnels, while armed guards are great at keeping your inmates surpressed. be sure to plan their routes properly and concentrate forces at critical points.  Rooms: a large variety of rooms, from different cell types (holding cells, solitary, regular) to security stations and armories to libraries and laundries for the prisoners. build a dog pound, common room or even a chapel for the those that want to find salvation in the arms of the lord. Cells have a quality, directly incluencing the inmates' behaviour. always good to have an eye on that ;)  Staff: Psychologists for intimate group seminars with the prisoners, grounds keepers, cooks and, of course, a lawyer and accountant. Let them research, clean and fend off annoying lawsuits or loss conditions. I told you, you are the boss :P  Prisoners: now, they are the true heroes of this game. quite clever and crafty little s. They will stop at nothing to try to escape you or send the prison spiraling down into a muderious abyss of blood and mayhem. building tunnels together with other prisoners. stealing the appropriate tools from around the prison. shanking suspicious inmates in the shower. initiating riots when a prisoner dies. Prisoners come in all forms and shapes. from the mid 20 stoner, in for possession, to deathrow inmates with multiple murders. some have abilites, some are even legen-wait for it-dary. and you decide their security level ;)  Snitchs and Ex Law Enforcement inmates are a painful joy. not fast enough in identifying them? see them shanked to death in the shower, yard or laundry.  There's a huge variety of prisoners, crimes and reputation skills, and each prisoner is indeed somewhat of an individual.  Intelligence: recruit confidental informants, check the history of contraband and control your gangs. but be careful, the more you rely on your informants, the more likely they are to be killed by their fellow inmates.  Logistics: still a bit of a pain in the  to get around with, but you can control who is washing which wings' clothes, preps their food etc.   Size: as they say, it doesn't matter. try to manage a small prison with few but maybe violent inmates, or go ballistic with hundreds of prisoners, likely suffocating in their own filth. Prison architect is fun from small to big. But always a challenge.  Random Events: Fires, floods, virus outbreaks and surprise prisoners, all the things you need to ruin your day.  While a burst pipe is easily taken care of, a fire can surely burn down large parts of your prison and kill many an inmate or staffer. Be sure to have either a quarantine ward ready for outbreaks, or to isolate the affected prisoners in their cells quickly.  Prison Policy Events: You can't run a prison without some politician or the other trying to boss you around. They will ask you to serve your prisoners the lowest grade food or to remove all work out benches from the yards, because some one clearly does not want your prison to be peaceful. ignore it and get annoyed by phone calls every few ingame hours, or just do as they ask and deal with the fallout. probably by bashing in heads and locking up half your prison  Campaign: a lovely little story revolving around betrayal, murder and mayhem, also serving as a perfect tutorial for the sandbox mode. The campaign introduces the mechanics in an understandable and easy to grasp way for new comers, and even after 100 hours, it still offered insight for my gameplay.  There is so much more going on, but seriously, 110 hours into the game I feel like I barely scratched the surface of what Prison Architect really has to offer. Even now, after 160 hours, it still sucks me in for 5 -10 hours a time. From the urge to build more and better wards to just observing the prisoners and try to keep the place calm, there is much to do and even more to observe.   Get it. This game is worth every Euro and Stotinki and will make you forget about everything else. There's still some bugs left, but the devs are still putting out updates, and so far the game as steadily improved.  I know I have probably been neglecting huge parts of the game in this review, but heck, I'm just one man trying to keep people locked up.",1,0,44522
233450,Prison Architect, Early Access Review,1,0,44639

35700,Trine,"I highly recommend this game if you're a fan of puzzle solving games, like smashing the hell out of skeletons and if you like the idea of having 3 characters merged into 1. I didn't get off it... It's a fantastic game with 3 characters that you can find different perk items for to maximise their abilities. It's also a great puzzle solving game as you have to use your initiative to navigate the missions. The wizard has awesome powers to conjur up platforms, boxes and bridges. The thief is great because she can reach high up places and the knight is just kickass for when you have a lot of enemies around you. I favoured the thief the most due to her ability to grapple onto any wooden surface and climb the grapple rope. Following her closely I favoured the wizard as he can get your other characters around very fast. I love the idea of having 3 characters merged into one interchangable character, makes the gameplay really smooth.This game took me 5 and a half hours to complete, and that was on medium. The last mission is pretty insane and very fast paced. It has a great immersive world and it can keep you occupied for ages. Great time killer as the missions aren't massively long but there are nifty little hide-aways that have experience vials and chests, that if you play with the intention to fully play a mission, can take you quite a while.   For a 2.5D game it is very enjoyable, I highly recommend it.   8/10",1,0,44962

251730,Legend of Grimrock 2,"This is essentially Legend of Grimrock, but more. There's a greater variety of enemies, the skill point system is tighter, there are different environments to traverse instead of an eternity of brick-and-moss walls to bump listlessly into, the fan community is generally helpful, and the game *can* be beaten by a casual dungeon-crawler without the need to refer to a walkthrough every five steps. That said, there are several major optional dungeons, old areas repopulate with new encounters after milestones in the plot, puzzle hints are scattered between zones to make back-tracks more productive, and classes have been added to the game, supplementing the new races with a broader range of build options at the game's start.  Grim II is substantially more intuitive, with the worst puzzles being largely optional and timing-gimmick traps an occasional thing, rather than a whenever-the-developers-got-bored kind of affair. Pixel-hunt walls are also less in evidence (although the workshop community is working dilligently to fix that,) and fish restock themselves in ponds and rivers to cut down on starvation-induced unwinnable game-states.   It is still possible to get locked into an unrecoverable state (invincible golems start appearing midway through the plot, and they can wall-abuse you into a corner if you're unlucky,) but rotating your saves will prevent this handidly.  Basically: if you even sort of liked the original game, you're going to have a good time.  If you didn't much care for Grim 1's formula, but you liked Eye of the Beholder or Ultima Underworld or similar titles, this is still worth a try.   The only people I'd suggest give this a miss are people who want a smooth, continuous flow of play ala Halo, CoD, Skyrim, etc. Grimrock is largely about stopping and thinking about how you're going to proceed, and folks who have a strong negative reaction to things like substitution ciphers would do well to stay clear.",1,0,46786
233450,Prison Architect,I like this game becoz it is nice and i like nice games beccaus they are good to play and make me do the happy?,1,0,46878

233450,Prison Architect,"If you buy this game, you may just be serving a sentence of your own...as time slips by, engroused in what you are doing. It's a fantastic managment, builder where the unpredictability of the prisoners (and pretty much everything else!) always has you interested.  The Pros: - Just one more thing: Oh how mnay times I've thought 'I'll just finish this bit and then I'll quit...no, wait, I'll do this bit too before I forget....oh and...' - Organised Chaos: Prisoners are fun to watch, can be easy or difficult to manage. I've built only 3 or four prisons (early access) and have had everything from zero problems almost at all, to a riot that started literally 3 seconds after I accidently overpowered my electricity generator (leaving one gaurd dead and many prisoners bloody and unconscious!).  - Loads of space to build - lots of info and lots to do. There's always plenty to do and work on.  - It's just damn fun and a good amouont of challenge  Take or leaves:  - Graphics: I like them, you should not be out off by them. There is a 3D mode, but it dodn't do much for me and I prefer the original personally - Prisoner mode: you can be one of the prisoners and try to escape your own or anyone else's who have shared it in the Steam workshop. It was ok when I tried it but no real sense of actually living in the prison from what I tried. A hit and giggle feature but maybe I need to check it out again.   Cons: - The tutorial and general information on how to actually play and whatthings do is very much NOT clear. I played the campaign tutorial a few times after extended breaks away from the game when it was in early access and I have avoided it this time around since its official release, so it may have been improved. But overall, you will almost certainly need to look up wikis and how to's, often for very simple thing. Thankfully, there is loads of community help and a working answer is easily found.  - Randomness that could be bugs or just lack of info: Sometimes you don't know why things are not working. Sometimes there are unclear clues, other times you 'll be cratching your heads (I have a few armed gaurds and security gaurds that gather together every night in the yard for no apparent reason. They are not scheduled to patrol there, but they do it anyway).   Really though, I find when I have a go at this game, I am sucked in for many long running sessions. Enough depth to satisfy a passionate builder/manager, not too much as to overwhelm. Eg, there are things like circuits and pressure plates, but you most definitely don't NEED them to run a prison (but it would help of course).  Very much recommended.",1,0,48740

270450,Robot Roller-Derby Disco Dodgeball,"So my friend and I were debating on whether or not to buy this game. I mean, yeah it's only $8 but we were a little strapped at the time. It looked fun, though, which is why we were hesitant. My friend decided to bite the bullet--he is the one with the better job, after all. I had to go handle my dog, so I was gone for the moment he downloaded it, but I saw the result. It was like nothing I'd ever seen before in my life. He used to be a fairly heavyset guy with pimples all over his face and an awkward demeanor; not unlike myself, though more so I suppose. The man I walked into that day was different. I saw a 6'3'' bronzed warrior with perfect facial hair and a gleam in his eye that could make any lady drop at his feet. His phone immediately started going wild with notifications about the millions being depositied into his brand-new Cayman Island account. At that moment, I knew what I had to do. I powered up my crappy laptop, barely even meeting the specs, and told Steam to install this game. At once I could feel my crotch bulging as I grew three whole feet in as many seconds. The scruffy excuse I had for a beard was replaced with a layer of hair so glorious Zeus himself was jealous as I also grew six inches taller. I wasn't a large man before, but any semblance of being out of shape melted away from my frame like butter in an oven and my muscles gained glory I'd only dreamed of before. Even my dog, who'd only been a pug before, now stood proudly by my side as a German Shepard-Husky mix while a beautiful woman appeared in my arms, who is now my wife. 271820,Card City Nights,"I bought this game when I only had a Netbook available to play games on. Had it on my wishlist since release and it's extremely cheap in comparison with some other games, so I just thought 'Why not?' and bought it. After starting the game you choose a character and give yourself a name. You're new in town and how else could it be, the whole town is crazy for card battles. The main goal of the game is to collect all legendary cards by beating the owners of those cards and finally beat the Card King. On your way you get to see lots of crazy looking, humorous characters and get to hear some nice chilling-jazzy tunes.  What I really like about this game is, that it's extremely fast and easy to learn, yet fun to manage your deck and finally use it in a card battle. To explain it very roughly, most Cards have arrows on them or some special effects and you just have to connect them on a 3x3 board to create combos using Cards that sum up to at least 3 Icons. Cards have one of four Icons on them, Attack, Defense, Revive and Neutral. Using attack Cards you can either attack your opponent and he'll loose 'defense' (just like Health Points) or disable one of your opponent cards, so he can't use 'em until he revives them using Revive Cards. Using Defense Cards will fill up your defense until you reach the maximum of 10 defense. Neutral Cards can come in handy when connecting Cards. You win a game when your opponent can't place a card on his 3x3 Board or he runs out of defense. Most opponents give you a card booster as a reward and you can also buy or fuse cards. I haven't spent much time collecting Cards, I just went on with the Cards I owned and updated my deck now and then, mostly only changing the legendary Card or replacing one or two Cards from my deck with Cards I got from a Booster.  While - at least in my opinion - you should never judge a game on how long it is (you don't pay 10 $ for a visit to the cinema and regret it because the movie was only 2 hours long, right?), Card City Nights entertained me for about 11 hours until I've beaten the whole game and got all the Achievements, which is quite long for a game that price. Instead a game should be judged by how fun it was to play and I really had fun playing it. I definitely recommend this game. It's fun, it's cheap, it has Steam Trading Cards and Steam Achievements. So: Why not?",1,0,11770
233450,Prison Architect, Early Access Review,1,0,11857
461430,EmergeNYC, Early Access Review,1,0,11939
251730,Legend of Grimrock 2,"Let me start off by saying I may complain a bit in this review but I still recommend this game. Also these are just my opinions of the game, I am sure there are many people who will say 'well I did not experience these problems blah blah blah' what I am saying is don't be butthurt by my opinion this is just what I have experience and felt for myself.   Cons-   Some puzzles are highly frustrating or very cryptic while I enjoy difficult puzzles some are extremely hard to decifer which can lead to frustration in people new to this type of game.  Some classes seem good but in reality they are not take the knight his dodge increase with shields is broken or at least it looks broken to me (will be patched if it is im sure)  Was not impressed with the alchemist guns there never seemed to be enough ammo and the guns were scarce. Potion making was awesome though.  Exploration was very fun in the beginning but later on it got very frustrating (for me).  Spells seemed weak IMO at times they would hit hard but most of the time even if the monster was weak to it they seemed over all weaker from the last game.  Characters seem to miss allot even if you get accuracy up until you get into the upper levels of accuracy.  Monsters can hit you over and over and over at times while you wait to recharge your characters attacks.  Near the end the boss fights just throw enemies at you which is not very fun they could have done something different with the boss fights to make them more interesting.  Puzzles get a little tedious after awhile because they are mostly just redos from previous puzzles with little differences.  Underwater battles are irritating especially if you don't have a trident or spear.  Not a whole lot of enemy variation.  I felt there were not a whole lot of weapon variations either but this may be nitpicking.  No voice acting from the master of the island (I feel a mysterious voice talking on his notes and maybe a random sentence when sleeping or something would have been awesome).  I know that most of the story is figured out with stone heads and notes from the island master but I feel at times besides looking for a way off the island you really didn't know why you were exploring the areas looking for power gems.  Armor sets do not have set bonuses so finding them all is good but doesn't make much of a difference.   Pros  I like the night and day cycle especially for some of the puzzles.  weapon special attacks were pretty good.  graphics looked good.(not that this really should count for scoring a game.)  Level design was great in most areas and it kept it fresh to have different level designs.  Most puzzles were fun to solve.  Map in this game is extremely helpful so is the compass and watch.  The armor sets looks cool even if they didn't get set bonuses.  Each enemy had unique attacks (don't drop the ethereal dagger)  Sound effects were done very well.  Potions made are very useful.  For the price lots of hours of gameplay especially with workshop dungeons and such.  Good unique character races with good pros and cons to using them.  While I enjoyed this game I also got much more frustrated with this one, way more than I did with the first one which is very very awesome (mine is owned from Good old Games and not in my steam account). By the time I got to the end of this game I was ready for it to be over, maybe I should have taken a break from it but it was interesting enough that I wanted to finish it. I will be taking a long break from it and then downloading allot of workshop dungeons when they become available and I feel like playing some more.  Graphics 7/10 Sound 8/10 Combat 5/10 Gameplay 7/10 Story 4/10 Replayability 9/10  Final score 6.6 or 7 rounded up definately worth getting.",1,0,11975

233450,Prison Architect,"First off I just want to say I was surprised by how well the campaign was written. I wasn't expecting much but it has quite some emotional impact.  The game itself is fun! There seems to be many possible ways to construct and run your prison, and I'd say the replayability is fairly high. It seems mostly bug-free and is functioning very well. It's mostly a very satisfying experience, if you like these kind of 'build and manage'-games.  It has some problems though. The most appearant is money balance. I'm not sure if I'm just playing it wrong, but I found it hard to earn money in a pace that allowed me to keep constructing and improving my prison without spending a lot of time waiting for money to tick in. There are some small glitches, the most annoying one i encountered was that my doctors kept getting stuck in the walls of my infirmary for some reason. I could fix it by ordering them to move somewhere, but until I did that, they would not function as usual. And after a while they'd end up stuck again. Firing them an rehiring didn't fix it. Some of the requirements for rooms are somewhat unclear. A couple of times I ended up rebuilding buildings because the room wouldn't function, only to later figure out I had made some stupid mistake like not tagging all squares in the building as part of the room. There is a bit of information that is hard or impossible to access in-game, and you have to go look at a wiki or something to figure it out. For example, connecting CCTVs to a monitor only works if you connect from the monitor to the cctv. if you connect from the cctv to the monitor, it doesn't work. There is no tutorial for these things in the campaign and that limitation is so incredibly odd yet mentioned nowhere in the game.  It looks like I've listed a lot of negatives, but most of them are actually relatively minor complaints. I've had a lot of fun with this game and it was well worth the money spent.",1,0,12679

233450,Prison Architect,"Figured I should get around to a review of this game after 100+ hrs..  Overview: Prison Architect is a game that allows you to construct, manage, and be sentenced to a prison of your own making with a large variety of features.  I typically do a pros/cons section in my reviews, but it's difficult to do that with Prison Architect. The game gives you the freedom to do pretty much everything with the tools it (or modders!) provide you. The AI for the prisoners and staff isn't bad, negatives like contraband, prisoner tension, and needs are fairly balanced with your mitigation options (Which require some thought in implementation!).  This game is everything you'd expect for what it is. The only true downsides that come to mind is that prisoners don't always satisfy their biggest need first (Such as not using the toliet sitting in their cells before going to the shower, then starting a fight over it.)  Vinal Verdict: Solid 9/10. Great game that's constantly being improved!",1,0,15739

251730,Legend of Grimrock 2,"Legend of Grimrock 2 (here on referred to as LoG 2) is everything you could want for a sequel and more. I look forward to what the future holds with user generated content.  The Legend of Grimrock series are a set of real time, grid based, dungeon crawlers with pleasing graphics and a good aesthetic.   Movement is based on grid and you can turn left and right also move left, right, forward and backwards. You attack by clicking the weapon of choice from the character portraits. While this is not for everyone, it's stays true to it's roots and will please many after they have adapted.  While the story is a little weak, you will find yourself enjoying the neatly packaged puzzles that are littered throughout the world. I had a problem with the first game where you had to search each wall for secret buttons or risk missing one. LoG 2 improves on this by giving some subtle and some not so subtle hints that the player is missing something and should look deeper, resulting in a less difficult search.  Another area that LoG 2 improves upon is allowing the user access to outside areas, giving more varied feel to the game. There are now many more types of enemies and many of which have varied A.I.  The soundtrack has seen improvements since the first game and has a lovely score of atmospheric ambient noise and battle music for boss fights. The theme tune is catchy but I still see myself returning to the theme song of the first game.  In conclusion my experience with Legend of Grimrock 2 was amazing and to top off it all, there is extensive support of modifications, I look forward to seeing what people create.  Controller Support : Not suitable for a controller. Fully playable with just a mouse.",1,0,17458

233450,Prison Architect,"Really good management game. You manage all aspects of a prison, from the rooms layout, electrical grid, and water distribution, to prisoners schedules, guards deployment, punishment policy, etc.  You can choose to punish a lot your prisoners or make them feel at home with nice cells and reform programs to help them go back in society, it's all your choice. Furthermore, the game offers a lot of technical items you can play with to fully automatize your prison, enhance security, etc. With all that, it's still noob friendly, and you won't have to play long to get the basics. 233450,Prison Architect,"Okay, I first time bought this game when it was in early access alpha 10. Boy, while it was buggy and laggy, I enjoyed every moment the alpha 10 provided and the next alphas as well. Some alphas had major bug fixing, some adding contents and a lot more. I edited a lot pages in the wikia of Prison Architect (The legal ones, aka, dev ones) and so on.  Now it got released. Is it really worth to buy this game? Absolutely YES! Are you the type of city building, money management, staff management, resource management, time management? Then this is your game.  At first you can do tutorial by doing missions. But the truth is, the tutorials do not really help you understand how the game works so you are forced to either watch some youtube videos or just check the wikias.  No problem! The  major positive  here is, the sandbox.   Unlike most other games which their sandbox often end because we filled out everything we had. For example, a survival horror with resources, if we got all resources, weapons to win our enemies, then we have nothing else to do because we got unlimited days to survive, etcetera.  So yeah, the sandbox is kinda limited, ESPECIALLY if you play it without money cheats or with challenges (Gangs, events temperature) and what not. If you got gangs ticked (Means they will make an appearance) it will add a challenge to the game and so on. On the other hand, you got a few guard types, one is a normal guard, one guard dog, one armed guard and so on and each of them got different roles and responsibilities! You can also hire cooks, janitors, gardeners and so on.  What you have to be really careful is, prisoners. They humans and express their needs by anger, arguing, fighting or worse, rioting. Riots is the worse challenge because if the prison is taken and hasnt been stopped for long time, the government will send military to take it over, thus marking it as game over (Unless FAILURE CONDITIONS are disabled).  Now, prisoners can eat, relax, sleep, work or attend to reform programs. That's good. On the bad, they will fight, be in a gang, escape from the prison, attack prison staff or other inmates.  You can build the prison YOU would like. You can make small cells, large cells, small canteen, huge yard and a lot more. NO limitations, you decide what you want! There are a lot rooms, a lot buildings to build, a lot staff to hire, a lot objects to place for a use, everything is everything, the sandbox simply never ends itself. You can even have more than 1000+ prisoners and the sandbox wont end, more challenges will come and more hard stuff.  There is escape mode too where you play as prisoner and escape from a prison, yours or someones. You can hire gangs, use tools to escape and so on but is too simple but fun.  And last pros, there is 3D mode which is very laggy and underdeveloped at the moment. You can download ANY mod you want from workshop!   On cons , the game has some very minor bugs which can be hardly noticeable unless you try hard. The lag is depending of your computer's processor, it has nothing to do with graphics card at most times.  This game is the best prison game I have ever played, better than Prison Tycoon. No other words, just no other words! I vote it...   8.5/10. Personally, I am recommending this game to ANYONE and especially to those who live kind management games which has endless sandbox mode and more good features. I dislike however, some bugs gone unnoticed and some lack features which in-real life prisons have such as multi-floor story, hostage situations and some. ",1,0,33625
